content.body: Hmm, why does locking an issue restrict it to people with write access. That's kinda prohibitive. Would be nice if there was a "has engaged with this organization prior to this issue" variant.
Well, the XSLT issue is locked to people with write access unfortunately. Can't be reading that all day.
Hah, yeah. I'll get that PR up to date.

annevk: writing tests now for styling of `:heading(n)`, I'm confronted with: should the default styles for `:heading(7..9)` also be tweaked? We could simply set them to the same has `:heading(6)` or something?
content.formatted_body: annevk: writing tests now for styling of :heading(n), I'm confronted with: should the default styles for :heading(7..9) also be tweaked? We could simply set them to the same has :heading(6) or something?

content.body: Feels weird that `:heading(7)` is now larger than `:heading(6)`
content.formatted_body: Feels weird that :heading(7) is now larger than :heading(6)

content.body: keithamus: ah, good point. Matching 6 seems reasonable, but not sure if that would violate some guidelines.
content.formatted_body: keithamus: ah, good point. Matching 6 seems reasonable, but not sure if that would violate some guidelines.

content.body: keithamus: maybe as part of adding `headingoffset`
content.formatted_body: keithamus: maybe as part of adding headingoffset

content.body: zcorpan: indeed
content.formatted_body: zcorpan: indeed

content.body: (Adding that attribute is what we're discussing.)

AFAIK there aren't guidelines on the visual size of a heading, only that they are in order. Anything close to looking like a guideline for each heading only mentions h1-h6... so I think we may be in slightly uncharted territory

Making the text even smaller seems bad, it would be unreadable. Bold italic could work, but only gets us another level. Maybe alternating bold / bold+italic? Another thing for authors to "reset" though
keithamus: I suggest we keep them bold, but give them all the same margins and font-size as `p`.
content.formatted_body: keithamus: I suggest we keep them bold, but give them all the same margins and font-size as p.

content.body: keithamus: I guess this does raise the question as to whether we spell it `:heading(7, 8, 9)` or `:heading(7), ...`. Meh.
content.formatted_body: keithamus: I guess this does raise the question as to whether we spell it :heading(7, 8, 9) or :heading(7), .... Meh.

content.body: I was going to hedge and spell it `:heading(7), ...` 😆
content.formatted_body: I was going to hedge and spell it :heading(7), ... 😆

content.body: `:heading(7)` is valid whether settle on `<AnB>` or `<integer>#` so it skirts the whole discussion/conclusion
content.formatted_body: :heading(7) is valid whether settle on <AnB> or <integer># so it skirts the whole discussion/conclusion

content.body: :nod:
Same as `p` matches no other heading style, but same font-size as :heading(4). Not sure that's better than matching :heading(6)
content.formatted_body: Same as p matches no other heading style, but same font-size as :heading(4). Not sure that's better than matching :heading(6)

content.body: Oh, I didn't realize. Wow. None of those defaults are great then.

zcorpan: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/images.html#sizes-attributes - if I say "if element has a sizes attribute", would that be false if the element had a `sizes` attribute but the value was invalid?
content.formatted_body: zcorpan: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/images.html#sizes-attributes - if I say "if element has a sizes attribute", would that be false if the element had a sizes attribute but the value was invalid?

content.body: Jake Archibald: no
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: no

content.body: I'm concerned about the "A sizes attribute is an attribute with requirements defined in this section." followed by "If present, the value must be a valid source size list."
So I was worried that it wouldn't 'have' one if it didn't meet the requirements
It's the DOM definition of attribute being present

annevk: I think we also want `headingReset` to be `true` when the Dialog is in the modal state. Whether or not the IDL reflects that I am unsure of, but I am sure we don't want to expect developers to manually add it so....

Do I add headingReset getter steps or do I add additional steps in the computed level steps?
content.formatted_body:
annevk: I think we also want headingReset to be true when the Dialog is in the modal state. Whether or not the IDL reflects that I am unsure of, but I am sure we don't want to expect developers to manually add it so....

Do I add headingReset getter steps or do I add additional steps in the computed level steps?

content.body: It feels like it shouldn't be getter steps, else `el.headingReset = el.headingReset` becomes weird
content.formatted_body: It feels like it shouldn't be getter steps, else el.headingReset = el.headingReset becomes weird

content.body: I wonder if it's a bit too magic in general.
Not sure that's a property we generally care about though. Hmm.
I'm perfectly happy just adding something akin to `or inclsuiveAncestor is a dialog whose is modal is true`
content.formatted_body: I'm perfectly happy just adding something akin to or inclsuiveAncestor is a dialog whose is modal is true

content.body: * I'm perfectly happy just adding something akin to `or inclusiveAncestor is a dialog whose is modal is true`

m.new_content.formatted_body: I'm perfectly happy just adding something akin to or inclusiveAncestor is a dialog whose is modal is true

content.body: I think we generally make the getter compute the actual state if we can.
That does create weirdness for the case Jake mentions, but I think that's generally weird because we compute quite a bit.

Interesting. Which other cases of this exist? I know stuff like `input.type = input.type` can set the attribute to "text" even if it was absent or invalid, but that seems fine (the default isn't contextual). `input.value = input.value` has side-effects, but… is that a good thing? `document.cookie` is a mess of course.
content.formatted_body: Interesting. Which other cases of this exist? I know stuff like input.type = input.type can set the attribute to "text" even if it was absent or invalid, but that seems fine (the default isn't contextual). input.value = input.value has side-effects, but… is that a good thing? document.cookie is a mess of course.

content.body: Eh, I guess you're right, you can't assume `obj.prop = obj.prop` is 'safe' on the web
content.formatted_body: Eh, I guess you're right, you can't assume obj.prop = obj.prop is 'safe' on the web

content.formatted_body: probably button.type which is contextual
